However, it seems like the bartenders sort of make up the prices as they go, like they're not really sure how much the drink actually costs. One night I paid $3 for a cocktail, and was charged $5 for the same cocktail a few weeks later. For those of us on a budget, it's kind of annoying when you have to spend more than you expected to. A little consistency would be nice.

This place got me in the New York Times! My roomies and I were there seeing my friend's band play, and check it out: http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2010/11/17/travel/20101121-SURFACING-5.html. That's me!I love it here. Great place to stop for a drink after sharking some surfers at sunset. Also, this was the last stop of my fake bachelorette party. My memory from that part of the day is fuzzy, but I'm pretty sure I had a great time.

It is what it is. Anyone that walks up to the Riptide and marks it as a quaint little tavern, a cool live music venue or somewhere to eat is fooling themselves. It's a dive bar pure and simple. The thing is that its the ONLY dive bar for like 10 blocks in any direction so if you are in the southwest corner of the Sunset it's the best bet.

The place is really chill. It didn't get busy until about 11, and that's when the music started getting good, too. My friend and I went on Thursday, Ladies Night, but there was probably 80% guys. The drinks are dirt cheap. I was amazed I got a cranberry vodka for $3 ($1 off for girls) when I was so used to paying up to $9 for those drinks in other places. The bartender, Brian, was EXTREMELY friendly, and I would go back just to say hi to him. He's there every Thursday apparently, so go find him, flirt a little and maybe you'll get free shots of Patron. ;)

What was once a great bar is being taken over by hipsters! I really am not sure what they are doing so far from the mission but I wish they would find their way home and give the bar back the the nieghborhood.

Oh, the Riptide. I love this place just as much as I hate it. I've spent many nights here enthralled by the drunken debauchery of the Sunset. It's one of the only bars in the neighborhood with cheap beer and decent music. I used to live down the street so it was easy to access if we decided last minute to head out for drinks. It helps that the L drops you off right in front and a cab ride back home used to be about $5 (if a cab is willing to even pick you up down there). It's a block from the beach so drunken walks to the sand are inevitable. However, I will advise that if you have never been before and you are not in the area don't make the trek over.They have beer specials and my favorite is Thursday night, Ladies Night. That's when all the crazies come out and the place is just packed. Needless to say there are very few ladies on Ladies Night so beware! They also have trivia nights, DJ's and bands playing from time to time. The crowd ranges from young college students, to locals and then really creepy men. I've had a few unfavorable encounters, actually I think everyone I know that has been there has had a few unfavorable encounters.I've come to the conclusion that you already need to be a few drinks in before heading to the Riptide otherwise you are just going to be disappointed. They also have happy hour but the Riptide during the day loses its charm mostly due to the fact that the crowd is tame and you can see the floors. It's a fun local spot and I'm grateful that the Tide has always been there for me on cold, foggy, lonely nights.To sum it up, the Riptide is a local dive bar located deep in the heart of the Sunset; You never know what your gonna get.
In the middle of the sunset. Awsome Irish bar...with a fire place. Nice place to warm up when it is cold in the sunset. I will be heading back here.

Many a bender has found me here, at least at some point in the bender.  Depressing, I know.  But how fun was it when we found out you could bring dogs, and ran outside and grabbed one?  Or all those times at the beach after?  Or that Velvet Underground experience?  There are many others that aren't worth mentioning until rehab, though.

The bar itself is great--good bartenders, pretty decent space, etc. But as for the crowd... well, imagine if all the popular kids from high school realized one day that they were washed up and decided to trade in their Abercrombie for flannel. Fipsters? Brosters? Brewsters? Basically, bros who have decided to pretend to be hipsters (without giving up their baseball caps or bench-presses) going to hit on girls who walked into Forever 21 looking for anything they could get their hands on with black and white horizontal stripes. Which is fine, but my friend and I felt really out of place. It's okay. Earlier in the evening (like, before 11:15, before it got really crowded) it was actually pretty good. Oh, also, watch out for the creepy older men. Really, it's high school with a creepy faculty.
A great local bar - please don't let the place turn in to a kennel club.....the doggie conduct gets old fast.  Maybe doggie hours and specials may help keep the pets in order.....just a thought

My friends and I have had our fair share of nights at this place, but simply because it was in the neighborhood (as in within walking distance). It's an OK place, with OK drinks, and pretty terrible service. They have live music here, not to my taste but to each their own. I do not generally like to give a bad review, but because the service here has sucked on more than one occasion, I had to voice my opinion. There was a particular time that my friends and I waited for 25 minutes to get the bar tenders attention, actually I should say for her to take our order not because it was crowded or  busy, but because she was talking to a friend. She acknowledged our presence and continued to chat away. When we finally did order the drinks they were not made right. There is no shame in saying "I am not sure how to make that", but there is something wrong about serving drinks that don't taste right. If you are coming here for a beer I guess it's an alright neighborhood spot, but for anything else I do not recommend it. We have not been here for a while and have no intention of coming back any time soon.
What can anyone say about a bar that pretends, or at least wants to be, a surfer bar but is nothing more that an Irish pub?? This joint has some serious identity issues. DO NOT waste your time!!
Decent bar, i wouldn't go out of my way to to here, but theres not a ton of other options in the area.

Aside from the proximity of this location to the actual shore, nothing about it said 'Beach Bar' to me as I read the awards on  the wall, boasting that this place was the best.It was a drizzly Sunday night and we found parking right across the street  so it was a quick walk in to listen to The Seducers. I think it was Honky Tonk night. It was fun; people drank and danced. I'd go back if I lived anywhere near the place and/or had a car of my own.
good specialsaverage pricesyounger crowdno pool table:(ok music

I made the pilgrimage here for the first time last Saturday evening to see Mike Beck & The Bohemian Saints play live. The music was great as was the establishment, beer selection and bar service. The barmaids were fast and attentive and provided friendly service despite how busy the place was. For you Guinness drinkers out there: The bartenders take their time to pour you the perfect pint, a lost art in most places. For those that panned this place in their reviews, I'm wondering if you were in a different bar? The only problem I have is that there isn't a cool place like this in my neck of the woods. I look forward to pouring down a few pints on my next visit.
What a great pub!  I was here for a fund raiser for the Save the Waves this past Wednesday night.  Such a great time.  The place was packed and the crowd was great.  It was very chill and laid back.

Stopped by after dinner with some friends in the Mission...decided to stop because another friend recommended it.... Definitely a younger crowd...As we walked though the door, we were greeting by a large aluminum tin with the reminants of some sort of appetizers crusted over in the bottom (nasty)...  The place was crowded and the bartender was over worked...  I expected more, but maybe I am spoiled by the Parkside Tavern just up the street.

If you like funky beach bars, this is your place. I have a theory that weirdos always hang out by the beach. Now I mean 'weirdo' in the nicest way possible. It is a solid, laid back atmosphere. Not a pub or a sports bar, but a beach bar. You get all walks of life in here- from beach bums to State students to weirdos like me and my friends.  The 'Tide is a good divey bar with alot of cool crap on the walls and the coldest beer in town. They have a different event every night of the week. The most popular is "Ladies Night" on Thursdays. Ask any girl that's been there about the free shot at midnight. Looks spectacular! They also have bingo, surf movie night, and open mic night. Live music acts and DJ's occasionally play as well.I've had many good, drunken times at this bar. Too good of a drunken time more often than not.  Not much more you can ask for. The owner is often there, and works hard to keep it a good place. He is also a great guy, so go up to him and say hello.  Don't go here if you are expecting a douchy marina bar with guys in knit jackets sipping on Cran-tinis. Unless you are a really attractive girl. Then by all means come here.

I guess I don't really think about drinking in my neighborhood so it took me years, and I mean years to check out this place.  The bars in the Sunset are usually dives but I guess it's the people that go there that count.  I came here with my surfer friend on a night where they were showing surf footage and raffling off a surfboard.  The place was pretty packed but given how limited they are on space there were about 20 people there.  I don't know if it was a special night or they do this all the time but they brought in food for everyone to share.  How nice. :)Oh, and P.S., we didn't win the surfboard....

A bar at the end of the world. In fact if the world is ending, this is where I want to be. After a day of exploring the beach, this was a perfect spot. Low key locals sitting around and watching the hockey game. A couple of dogs lazily sleeping the day away in the corner. A beer and a makers for $9. Good times.

I am bias because I live two blocks away and this is the closest bar to my house, but this bar is totally awesome. Drinks are well priced, crowd is super friendly and you never really have to wait longer than 20 mins for a seat. Also, its usually pretty crowded even on weeknights!
I love this place.If you're unfortunate enough to be all the way out here, forget about your misfortune in this warm and cozy bar which pours their drinks stiff to keep you there.

This is a great bar to have a few drinks then step outside and see the sunset, in the Sunset!  Usually really easy to park on street.  The locals are a great mix of folks you'd see in various neighborhoods of SF.  Easy to come in and get a drink and have a good time.  Used to be a dangerous dive, but it has been renovated and cleaned up nicely and is now a great spot to escape from SF and stay in SF!

Cool little hokey spot way out there in the Outer Sunset.  It'll just be packed with locals wearing plaid flannel shirts and blue jeans on any given weekend night.  They seem to be pretty chill, when I went there was a group at a table who straight up just brought a bag of Trader Joes chips, dip, and cookies to snack on while they drank and watched the bluegrass band play.  The decor and ambiance of this place makes you feel like you're in some Alaskan hunter's watering hole.  Totally out of place in a city like SF yet at the same time.. expected.  Pretty standard beers on tap, but hey they had Lagunitas IPA so I was happy.  I was the only Asian guy in the entire bar when I went, so that was new.

Love the Riptide - fun bar and it definitely reflects the folks living out here from the five or so times I've been here (always with a neighborhood local).Jeff (?) the guy who tends bar also runs the place and does a lot to give back to the local community hosting fundraisers for all kinds of groups and is a really nice guy.Definitely a cool bar to support out in the Sunset!
great neighborhood bar! dog friendly! the only thing is it opens kinda late not till like 4 oclock.
Fun place and bingo was great! Firsttime there and I won the pot woohoo! Cheap beer and drink specials and a good neighborhood bar, will def go again!

The decor of this place, the mural on the outside and the moose head on the wall really caught my attention! It is a really nice place, the bartenders are awesome, and the drinks are cheap and good! My only complaint was that this place was crawling with hipsters, which is always a drag, but it's not going to  stop me from coming back to this place.

Thanks to the Riptide there is a fun place to go in the Outer Sunset.  Instead of having to venture across town and pay $25 for a cab ride home - you can simply waltz over to this colorful and warm establishment, enjoy some drinks with friends, and walk home.  The bar is right at the center, so you can walk to either side for drinks, and the bartenders are friendly and at your service.  There is a variety of seating, good music, and friendly neighborhood people to make your time more enjoyable.  Not pretentious, very cozy, and oh so Sunset, I think the Riptide is a fabulous place to spend some time with friends.
Laid back neighborhood bar, with a fireplace. The bartender once gave us marshmallows to roast.

Were they once shut down for serving alcohol to minors?Even though we live in the hood, we drive. Find parking, since it's not a huge problem in the sunset... get to the door.Doorman asks to see my I.D. I show it to him.Get inside, it's a bit crowded for  a Thursday night. By crowded I just mean there is no where to sit my ass down. Patrons sitting at the bar don't seem to understand the five people rubbing against the back of them are REALLY thirsty. No one budges... thanks. Bartender FINALLY acknowledges us but with hesitation...she takes two friends orders. Ten minutes pass, then she takes the remainder of our group (that's only three).Bartender asks to see me I.D. I show it to her.Twenty five minutes later, we all finally have beverages. Parties of two are hogging tables that seat four, so we are still standing. Not a HUGE problemo. Since I'm standing I'll dance a little bit. But what the hell is this song? I can't seem  to find the beat? Music is awkward.My cell phone rings.. I'm gonna go outside to take this call.Stepped outside the door for two minutes and try to come back in.Doorman asks to see my I.D. I....show it to him.Do you see a pattern? This place just keeps rubbing me the wrong way... me and my friends down our drinks and take the night to a whole new level in the mission.

This bar is exactly what I want when I go to the Sunset in the afternoon for a beer.  Good service, awesome wooden tables, great juke box, nice staff, clean bathrooms and four friends having a beer at a table.  Only think that would have made it better is the fireplace wasn't on yesterday.

Another cool bar ruined by DJs.OK bar owners, music is great. Music adds to the atmosphere, and I *want* music in my bar. I also go to bars to talk to people. When the music is SO LOUD that I have to YELL to talk to the person I'm with, it ruins the atmosphere. It also makes me take my money elsewhere.Last night (10/1/09) was a *perfect* example.  A guy was playing some really cool music. However, he just kept turning it up louder and louder. About halfway through my first (and only) beer, I decided to move to the side room - but there was a speaker in there too. There wasn't a single place in the bar to escape. This place could be the ultimate neighborhood bar. Now it's just another hipster hangout with overpowering ironic music. Puke.And DJs. Your giant stack of old vinyl records looks all sorts of cool next to the fixie you can't ride, but worn out records *sound like shit*. Mmmmkay? Some of the stuff you were playing last night was so worn out it was unlistenable. If it had been something that was only available on ancient, thrashed records, it *might* have been excusable. What you were playing was good, but it wasn't rare enough to *require* you to play old, shitty, worn out copies of that record. Take some damn pride in your music collection (and by "pride" I mean quality of the actual recording). And point the fucking speakers at your head so you have *some* clue as to how loud it is.

This is a legitimate dive bar. No better place to catch a buzz near a fireplace, enjoy some fresh salty air, watch surf or music videos, listen to an open mic, and generally have a good time. The owner is a super chill dude who's usually there when I go. The bartenders are all pretty cool too. Bring your friends, get rowdy, and dance with some ugly chicks.

Used to live around the corner. Good neighborhood bar, nice decor for a *dive*. Good live music when they've got it. The fireplace kicks ass in the winter, and on those foggy summer nights when it feels like winter. The bartenders I remember were always cool, used to have an open mic, maybe still, that was pretty good too. I like the bar itself, roundabout, usually down to earth locals in there, surfers, blue collars, salt of the earth, good happy hour.

I have never had a bad time at this place.1. I am going back tonight in order to have another good time2. tie one on 3. make some random friendsall these can be done here without a problemwhy not 5 you ask, because i am not feeling generous

This place reminds me of college, when all was right in the world, being sort of broke and drinking every weekend. Or even some weekdays. Whatever.Don't come to the riptide if you want some sort of scene. Come here to drink and be nice. And you can bring your dog. Monday night open mic has the best guy on piano doing Queen songs, you've gotta check him out. I think I tried to flirt with him in front of my boyfriend. Anyway. Love the jukebox, sometimes they'll even load some free tunes for you if you ask. Most of the bartenders are great, you know, relaxed, nice. There's a bitchy girl or two, but I assume they'll leave eventually and get a job at Delfina or something.Although there's been an influx of lame lately (customer-wise), Riptide will always be special to me! Once again, if you're looking for more than a place with beer where you can hang out with your friends, you should probably look elsewhere. If you want a dive bar, you've found it.

Super chill, went here a couple times on a Monday night just to kick it with friends, and there were more people in there then one would assume...but we all know what assuming does...anyways, nice crowd, dogs run amuck, there is a moose head on the wall and open night mic. Definitely a good neighborhood joint, although the bartenders seem to have hearing problems and constantly get drink orders wrong, but they're usually pretty nice so i'll let it slide.

One of my favourite bars in the city. I knock one star off as one or two of the bartenders are really spacey and the beer selection could be a little more diverse - Chimay or Leffe perhaps? PBR on draft?

Decent in a Cheers way. If you're a single lady looking to meet some hotties, don't come here if you expect them to be fashion-concious. Speaking of dogs, you can bring them here.. but be careful petting other people's dogs because I've noticed on several occasions that even the dogs here aren't so clean; After I pet them, my hand reeked of schtanky dog.. nothing better than your drinking-hand smelling like wet-cheeto-otherpeoples'dog-funk. But relax, they have Nick Cave on their juke box.

Good drinks, good people. Very relaxed cozy atmosphere... bonus in the winter is that they throw wood on the fire. The only down side is there is no outdoor seating... if it had that it would be a 5 star.

Rolled in here after going to the beach and really liked this place. It was sunday night around 7 and they had live old timey music and $2.50 pbr bottles. The bartender was nice, and the crowd was a very cool mix of locals and others.If I lived around here this would be my local place, i'll be back.

One question: Where were all the mullets and curled mustaches? Perhaps my experience was outside of the norm, where I expected to step into a divey drinking hole from the 1880's...or 1980's. Instead I was generally bored, unsatisfied and surrounded by rude people and not (18,19)80's rude!Luckily, once I got past the woman practically grabbing money out of my wallet to give to the DJ, I settled into some pretty cheap drinks and enjoyed the decor. The 'tenders were pretty cool and it sounds like it may be a better experience on regular weeknights. Especially when you're all the way in the Outer Sunset!
I forgot to mention this place has absinthe and they serve this in the most impressive way.   If you are a fan, you really should check it out.

Wet Wednesday = Surf Movies and free food brought over from Brother's Pizza, which is right next door.Lady's Night Thursdays = $1 off all drinks for girls. I got my PBR for $1.50 last Thursday, which made me pretty amped.Friday's Happy Hour = free home style food and cheap drinks! It's a good place to get drinks, sit by the fireplace, and eat Brother's Pizza. Definitely my favorite bar in the Sunset!!

Love this bar. 2 blocks from the beach,  this place is a local surfer/hippie/working guy and gal kinda place. That's MY kinda place. The owner likes bluegrass so they often have a bluegrass bands on the weekends. There's a fireplace, the funnest, silliest BINGO game on Sat nights from about 6-8pm, and one of the bartenders makes one of the best Margaritas in town. This place is just down home fun!

Completely amusing for my friend's birthday venue, and a place that you could easily fly solo to - because everyone is in their own world, friendly enough to talk to you if you want, and there's enough weird crap on the walls and ceilings to gawk at.  Locals bring their dogs, the "DJ" plays Neil Diamond covers, and the bartenders are nice.  I'm never in this area, but I wouldn't hesitate going again.  Parking is easy!
I went here for the first time last Friday and loved the live metal/rocky dj. found the drink prices to be fair.Fun decor.I would totally go back even though it's way the fuck out there
Solid, divey cheap bar with plenty of parking available near it.  Went here for a birthday party, and had a great time.

Friend of mine is a regular here. She insisted we motor from IR to Sunset and back claiming it was so good! Wasn't disappointed when we got there. Fun people. Dogs on leashes running about. Wrap around bar. Regulars getting up all on other regulars. Good times. Until time was up. Two female bartenders, one told the other "give them a count down and tell them to get the hell out" we downed those drinks and dashed.
Friendly staff, cool patrons, cheap drinks, and good tunes.Can't really ask for more.

a bit on the small side, a lot on the funside.oh... the craziness that goes down in the sunset. One particular time i vividly recall is when out-of-town males took off their shirts and danced their arses off. 1-stall bathrooms are impractical.service is okay.
Although when I went it was super packed inside and hard to move, I still really liked this bar. The drinks were pretty cheap and the dj was spinning some good tunes.  It's a great little local bar.

You know that old song "Brandy"? It goes, "Brandy, you're a fine girl, what a good wife you would be. But my life, my lover, my lady is the sea." I believe Brandy works here. No reason, I just do. And that song happens to be a guilty pleasure of mine, so that's a plus in my book. The Riptide is a neighborhood bar and seemed to be populated by local Irishmen, surfers, and other men of varying ages and drunkenness. Girls, there's no need to dress up. The other women there definitely don't. There's a fireplace, too, which is cool, even if they do light the fire during Save the Air fire prohibitions.I also like the Riptide because it is the only San Francisco bar I can go to that when I tell people I live in Pacifica, they don't look at me like Pacifica is somewhere just south of Guam. In fact, when my friend said she lives in Potrero, they looked at her like she was the foreigner, you know, bringing gifts from far away, but making it clear she cannot stay . . . no harbor is her home.

The Riptide quite divey, in every sense of the word.  For a place way out in the boonies, it is poppin.  And the prices are very reasonable.  And definitely a place for locals to hang out.Lady that came around with the tip boot?  If the jukebox played better music, the boot would be fuller.  Just a note.

Having lived in the Mission and Lower Haight for the last ten years, I haven't ever been in the situation of my electricity going out and no bar within one block to go to...ever.  Tonight, I came home to a dark block and dark house.  Remembering that the closest bar is the Riptide (and I have never been there), I eagerly went to go have a drink and wait out PG&E.  Plus I've been meaning to try this place out for a year or so, since moving into the much less bar-dense Sunset.  Maybe nice to get drunk less than a $30 cab ride from home once in a while, right? Once inside, I noticed that it is very similar, but smaller, in layout  as the Uptown on 17th and Capp.  Wraparound bar, but smaller main room and no pool table.  There was a dub DJ playing in one corner.  I stood at the bar, trying to decide what I wanted.  The bartender didn't look at me.  Not, she didn't look at me until she was ready for my order; She never looked at me once the 5 minutes I stood at the bar.  Literally in front of her.  I tried to make eye contact.  Nothing.  She wasn't that busy.  I myself am a bartender and am very understanding when it comes to waiting one's turn.  I also hate it when I am obviously busy and some A-hole comes in and thinks that they are the only one waiting.  However there was nothing.  Three of four minutes after I'd been standing at the bar, literally in front of her (no "hi" or "give me a sec" or "I'll be right with you".  Just nothing.  Then a  dude came up to the bar next to me.  "What are you havin honey," she asked, and served him a beer.  Thats cool.  Then another dude comes up to the other side of me and she serves him.  I look at her, she doesn't look at me.  Maybe I smelled bad, I don't know. Suddenly I realized I don't want to be at the Riptide,  and I say F-it and go home.  Screw you riptide, PG&E was done, my lights are on, and I'm not coming back.  So now I am going to have to go on the hunt for a nice, friendly, sunset bar.  Sweet!

I love this place.  Don't know why, it's nothing and everything all rolled into one.  It isn't a dive, and it's not hip, yet it teases you with both adjectives. You get the surfer crowd, the old irish crowd, the student crowd, and miscellaneous locals.  I've been there on nights with a DJ, live music, open mike, and on quiet nights when it was cold and foggy outside and I cozied up by the fire with a beer and the crossword.  Patrons and barkeeps are always cool/friendly, etc.  I've taken tons of people and everyone leaves saying "what a cool little bar."  Its one of those really-special-nothing-special kinda places--just the kinda place I like.

Is it kinda creepy to name the bar by the beach where there is a helluva deadly riptide, the same? Maybe a warning, maybe an homage, by the second drink you stop thinking about it. The Riptide has the feel of a locals hangout, with friendly patrons, happy dogs, old cedar furniture accents, and a fireplace. Movie night. DJs some nights. A juke box with a pretty swell variety of cuts. There was a Thursday night about a year ago that included cut up hot dogs in water in a crock pot. Apparently they do free bar food. By 1am it doesn't look too bad with some relish.The bartender didn't know how to make a Mexican Martini (proper noun, not racial slur!), but put together a pretty decent margarita with top shelf tequila on the house when I carried the boot around for the DJ, to encourage tipping. Ah, it felt like home. And reminded me I need to buy some cowboy boots.

I was a bit terrified about doing my first open mic night... This place was jumping for a Monday night ( a little more intimidating) but the staff and the crowd of locals could not have been nicer and more encouraging. Simply perfect!

they have a fireplace and were open on the most frickin boring xmas day ever, which turned out a fun xmas night after all, even if a little bizarre in its own way for my own reasons.  a very chill hangout but way far out there by the ocean, which is probably a plus in its favor actually.

It's cleaner and more lively than the old Sand Bar and has a good DJ on the weekends. Alas there aren't many other options out here. However, watch your money in this place. In the last two visits,  I had one bartender  shortchange me and another was swiping  / palming any and all money off the bar as a "tip" I suppose, including the money I was going to use to buy my next drink. . My money was near the edge of the customer side of the side of the bar next to my drink. The bartender comes by, takes my next drink order, takes away the old glass, swipes my Five and then asks for the money when she delivers the drink.  Twice in a row here...a little bit shady.

This place is a great neighborhood bar. Built in 1941 The bar has rustic brick flooring and high ceilings, the original knotty pine walls and a raging fireplace. Strong drinks. Friendly patrons. There is space for a DJ and some dancing. There is a jukebox. The bar is one block away from the Pacific Ocean. Benches galore outside for smokers. Bingo night and other theme nights. I will be back.

cool spot...  chilled out and always a good vibe in there...  sometimes its packed and sometimes its dead...  been there on saturday nights when it was one or the other...  wednesdays are the best though for happy hour and appetizers for a good time!  the dj's are kinda lame from time to time i think but im sure i might be alone in thinking that sometimes...  haha...

I haven't been here in a while but I used to live close to the Riptide and I miss the place!  It is by no means anything fancy or amazing but the drinks are cheap and strong so if you are just looking for a low key night in the neighborhood then this is the perfect spot.

I'm not sure if its fair to give the riptide only three stars because I've only been once but too bad, you get three stars.  I feel like people love this place because its one of the few bars out that far.  Its filled with surfers, people who like surfers, people who like the beach and people who don't want to live close to town.  (I feel weird saying "town" but there you have it.)  I don't surf, I didn't grow up in a surfing culture and the beach to me is hanging at the Jersey boardwalk so yeah, its not my scene.  HOWEVER, the vibe is friendly and I do enjoy their Beach Chalet beers on tap but its small, reminds me of a bar I would find located next to Mo'Bags in Mt. Olive, New Jersey.  I should note Mo'Bags is in a strip mall.  Its definitely a neighborhood bar which is why it probably gets 3 stars, because its not in my neighborhood and I'm not willing to drive or take public transit down.  I pass too many other places I would rather hang out at.If one does live in the neighborhood I can see the appeal; movies projected up on the wall and free food sometimes.   If you live out there and haven't checked it out, definitely stop by OR if you surf in the area its a must stop.  Otherwise, eh.

I went to SF to visit an old roommate and this was the first bar he took us to (after grabbing a burrito at a joint up the street and eating on the beach).  Oh man!  It made me want to move to San Francisco immediately.  If there are bars this awesome, I want to be able to walk to them, or at least take public transportation to them.  The fireplace was warming and a touch that bars back East don't seem to have.  The beers were reasonably priced, the crazy wooden tables were awesome, and the jukebox solid.  I plan on going back to San Francisco and hope this bar will, again, serve me my welcome beer.

They have a fireplace.. with board games. Battleship anyone? hell yes. This is a great place to hang out with your buddies and down a few beers.  Friendly bartenders.  Went here for a friend's 21st bday and the entire bar got a free shot. love it.

Next stop, the Pacific Ocean. This is literally a great bar at the end of the earth. Surfer vibes, chill music, good drinks, friendly staff and killer DJ's. Check their site and look at the calendar. There is something for everyone. Oh, and they have a working fireplace. Just sayin...

my favorite local bar in the sunset.  i don't know if it is the fireplace or the deer head on the wall, but something about this place makes me feel like i'm back home in the midwest. it also helps that there's something going on (and when i say that, i mean either drink specials or free food) every day. thursdays are ladies nights, and every thursday it seems to magically be some bartender's "birthday" and all the ladies in the bar are called up for a free shot. this is definitely a local place, the crowd is chill and dogs are welcome. i can't ask for anything else.

It Takes a Village to get a drink at the riptide. If you are a woman, send your man up to get a drink for you, apparently most of the bartenders don't like other women.The two doppelganger piranhas are incredibly beautiful, but their souls are cold as ice and their mean nature makes them ugly.The bad attitude of these weekend bartenders is tolerable only because there is no where else to go on the outer rim for blocks, and blocks, and blocks.I am boycotting the nights they work, and drinking tall cans with the hobos by the sea--anything is more entertaining than being treated badly for no reason.
Very chill local spot. And, surf movie night on wednesdays...!

This place is a great low key pub that allows dogs and has a fire place.  The drinks are good, the crowd varies but is usually good and the fire is a great when it's cold and foggy.  There's also the great Brother's Pizza right next door so you can order your pizza, then pop over to the riptide for a pint while you wait.  The L is a half block up, so this is also a great place to go when waiting for the train.
Love this place. Came on a Sunday afternoon and I can't wait to go back. Perfect for just hanging out with friends. I want to be a regular, however, I don't think I'm quite there yet.
Love the local dives!  nearby and festive...

It is your home away from home. Rip Tide is a nice little pub in the ol'Sunset neighborhood that attracts the locals.  If you are looking for a scene, pick up joint, or something trendy this is not the place.  If you like to roll out in your PJ's and listen to a variety of music with your friends kicking back cheap drinks, then this is the place. Oh, and dogs are welcomed too!  On Wednesdays they show surf movies and sometimes  cool, local surf bands will be playing the sounds of the tropics.  This is an ask no questions type of place. You will not witness any one trying to be cool or profiling like most places in San Francisco. You can be yourself here and interact with real people.  There are loads of seats, fireplace, and tv's.  If you want a low key night and can't find anything to wear this is wear you should be..

I dislike this place but the extra star is for the Shaun White look-a-like jumping off of barstools.  All of the guys here were meh and we took off after one drink.  Thank you outer sunset for reminding me why rents are so cheap out here.  There's nothing to do.

Once again, like places I can sit.  They have an awesome fireplace, they have cool stuff on the walls, and its a few blocks from my house and THE BEACH.They play Surf movies on Wednesday, they have an open mic (which is usually older men, sunset locals... but still good and entertaining).The staff is friendly and they have specials.  Sometimes they do fundraisers for Surflike foundation and it gets PACKED, but it really is a great lil place to get some booze.  And scenic.
This place is a great place to knock a few back on a Sunday afternoon.  Or anytime really.  Comfy and hassle free.
Ah, what can I say about my go-to bar?  Dive, beach, dogs, locals, awesome.  Alisha, Jeff, Joanne, et al, you guys rock.Little known fact: best margaritas in town.

Here are two things you never wanted to know about me: I am a judgmental bitch from Los Angeles & I cannot drink enough to make ugly people good looking.  Terrible, I know.  The Riptide is a cute neighborhood bar that welcomes good-looking surfers and the neighborhood cows that flock there.  I guess what I am trying to say is that this is not a TENs bar, so feel free to come here and hook up with guys that are better looking than you because they do not know any better.

Cozy little neighborhood bar.  They do a good job having fun here!  Last time I was here, two cops walked in, chatted with a patron for a few minutes, put him in cuffs, and then walked him out to the car and took off.  Huh?!?  I'd expect something like that at the pittsburg or flannahans (not to take anything away from those fine establishments...quite the contrary...it would just add to their rustic charm).  Nice having muni right outside - it's like having a private driver!

For all those who wish to bask in the glory of the foggy sunset, get yourself a drink at the Riptide and cheers to you!  This place is cozy, decent music overhead and they can make you any drink you like.  Occasional dancing on the bar and some good guest live acts and DJ's. My only question: Does anyone know the guys name with glasses that is always there looking to by someone a drink?... creepy.

This is easily the best neighborhood bar in Parkside/Outer Parkside.  If you are looking for a fun place way out in the Aves for a couple drinks, this is the place.  If you are looking for a "scene," you should probably not be looking in Parkside.  The live music is always fun, but not always great.  The White Trash Happy Hour is a must do.

Great escape from the masses. This bar is always fun and the bartenders could not be nicer. The drinks are cheap too by SF standards. On Sunday they feature live music and there is usually BBQ or hotdogs or something to eat as well. Yay, booze and food.

The Riptide makes you feel like you've left the city, and you almost have! At the end of Taraval street, it's full of surfers, Irish construction workers, ages that run the gamut, including an 80 year old ex-fireman with great stories, and surprisingly enough a lot of native San Franciscans!  The bands tend toward Americana, including bluegrass, country, etc, and did I mention the music is always free? My favorite country band, Red Meat plays occassionally to a packed house. One side of the bar is perfect for watching the band and the other for hanging with your friends at authentic driftwood tables. The decor is funky nautical, of course. Ocean Beach is only a block away and they have a killer 4th of July bar-b-que!  The majority of the bar staff are adorably cute girls who seem to be having a great time. Definitely my favorite dive in the city.
The place is okay! It was dead empty and it took the bartender like 15 minutes to even notice me sitting at the bar! Whatever! For some reason the Stella was like the worst tasting Stella ever!

I don't care what anybody says about you Riptide, I love you anyways.Fireplace, dogs, good beer on tap, surf movies on Wednesdays, free food on Wednesdays, near the beach, pizza place next door, live music, super divey... what more could you ask for?

Stumbled in at 12:30. Ordered two beers, only had six bucks. Went to the ATM, I was overdrawn. Went back, stood in front of the nice cute barkeep sweating awkwardly until B. came back with the cash.10 minutes later, three nice young ladies, including the blonde barkeep we slighted, were dancing on the bar in front of our faces.DJ was on Friday, he was wasted but played a fucking great set. Dirty martinis were delicious. Decor is a riot. See you again soon, R.T.

If you live in the area it's nice.. not too expensive and typically a good crowd on weekends.  Some nights are crowded, they do have a DJ and live bands.  I saw a band with an electric accordina there, that was sweet.  Ill give them credit for trying they have posters up in the sunset talking about all the events they are doing.Just not my scene, you cant dance, very loud and a weird set up.But check it out

It's a pretty small place and it is out in the boonies ... but it's also super chill and relaxed.  This is perhaps one of the only non-old-chinese-people places in the sunset and thank goodness for that.

I spent quite some time in Nevada City at one point in time (because of love, not because of insanity). The Riptide reminds me EXACTLY of a bar I have been to several times in Nevada City. This is good for me (memories) and bad for an SF establishment (mullets). Still, a good blue-collar time can be had by all. There are lots of boys in their 20s here. If you like boys in their 20s, this is a good place to cruise. Cougars, take note.There's live music. At least there was live music the night I was there. And after a few PBRs, you can dance around like a freak fool and no one will care at all. The location means you should probably drive but the alcohol component means you should probably walk or take MUNI. Which explains who all of these strange people are. They're beach people. And beach people are a whole other breed.

The Riptide rules!I actually heard some good vocalist on open mic night.  I love the live music on the weekends.  Who doesn't love ladies night.   If you live in the outer sunset and you and you can't handle the trek to the mission or lower haight then I say the Riptide is the place to be.I love the moose head and the wood cut tables too.  It's almost like you're in a club house.  It reminds me of a bar that I would find in a small town, so It brings me back and makes me feel at home.

Walking into this place at almost midnight on a wednesday with 6 girls definitely got us some attention...a chill crowd, everyone was pretty friendly, even though I think some of them left because we were rowdy. Jeff the bartender was super sweet and gave me a free beer for my bday!  his other drinks were strong and the red-headed-slut was fantastic. he was even a gentleman when our drunk as a skunk friend hit the table and knocked over 5 glasses which he had to clean up, despite our attempts to do so. then he was even more gentleman-ly when i accidentally knocked a glass out of my friends hand (i still think it was partly his fault..) thanks jeff!! wet wednesdays were cool, old surf movies and a fireplace, plus a piano, dj, and plenty of boardgames. and clean bathrooms!! high five. ill def be back :)

Slow night on a weekend night....I'm not sure if I like or dislike their strange indoor layout of almost two rooms...Bartenders were not very nice, nor friendly...Liked the name, wish it lived up to the beach-bum-name though...

The first time I heard someone playing an electric ukulele I did not think I would find myself in the midst of one a second time... by choice or chance. It is just not the sort of instrument that should be played out of its traditional form, which does not include wires or plugs. I certainly did not think I would find myself in the midst of one at a bar that I fondly remember as the Sand Bar, a drug den and downtrodden stomping ground settled on the edge of civilization in the Sunset. However, this is no longer the Sand Bar. It is now the Riptide and instead of witnessing a deal going down or a brawl ready to erupt by the fireplace tucked in the back you have to stand back a bit and listen to someone bastardize music in a venue much too small for even a good musician to play. The decor has cleaned up since the days of the Sand Bar as has the clientele. The drinks are a fair price and the service is efficient. The majority of the drinkers here look to be a nice mix of semi-wholesome boozers who come here because there really isn't anything else around. I wonder what happened to the shady characters who used to come here.....I would pay them double the price of whatever they were slinging to take care of the guy with the uke.

Although I don't get out to the Riptide as often as I would like, each time I've gone there I've had a great time. Whether just chilling, watching a sporting event on tv while sipping some vino or listening to live music and chatting with fellow patrons, it's always a relaxing and friendly atmosphere. The bartenders are fabulous and the only possible negative about the Riptide is that I wish they opened earlier on weekends.

The Riptide is a delightful neighborhood bar that can provide some real surprises. Not only a friendly place to drink a beer (or a few) but I've seen Kitten on the Keys and the Hot Pink Feathers dance on the bar!

One of the best neighborhood bars in the City and with a pretty cool name. It's a stone's throw from Ocean Beach and its laidback vibe like, totally matches the lazy-ass surf. Maybe it's the beach's proximity, but it just seems like everyone's in a good mood and I even noticed strangers striking up conversations with each other. You're as likely to run into a surfer as you are to spot a dog or two up in here and sometimes the quadrapeds are fun to have around. The fireplace at the back makes for an even more inviting atmosphere. The jukebox plays everything from Aretha to Bo Diddly to The Clash.

My boyfriend took me here on our first date. When I first walked in, I noticed that I was a little over dressed by wearing skinny jeans and high heels. (The next time I knew I had to wear tenny's and a sweatshirt)Luckily we were early and found seats. BC by 10 it was packed.I recommend the Riptide Red for the low cost and tasty taste.We go there all the time, just to grab a drink and relax.

Great neighborhood bar!!!  They have a fireplace, show old movies from time to time, and provide locals with a relaxing, warm, and friendly environment to sit back and have a drink.Get to the riptide this instance!!!!

At Taraval and 47th, The Riptide is about as physically isolated from the rest of the city as a bar can be, but it also stands alone in a figurative sense.  Maybe it's the crowd of friendly surfer dudes (and the girls who love them) and Orange County expatriates; maybe it's the mounted moose head and alligator skull, or the polished driftwood tables; whatever the reason, this bar made me feel eerily far from home, like I had walked in on something intimate and secret.I like that they have a fireplace, cool DJs (who happened to be spinning some sweet new wave and post-punk when I visited), and a few beers you're not likely to find anywhere else.  Surf movie Wednesdays and free live shows will definitely warrant at least a few return visits.

This might be the coolest bar in the city (Shhhhh!!! don't tell anyone i said that) Once inside you could be in the midwest for all you know. taxidermy (moosehead that was drooling mistletoe for the holidays), good music, cozy fireplace, cute surfer boys, friendly bartenders (free drink on my birthday). first time i went here i definitely got looks like i was from outta town. i like that.

I really like the Riptide.1. I can walk there2. My dog is perfectly welcome inside3. The bartenders are super nice and never let my drink stay empty very long.4. Have a cool fireplace5. They play surf videos on Weds. and they are usually pretty cool and somewhat obscure videos.It is very easy to drink more than you originally anticipated at the Riptide.  Not sure why.  For my number reasons above this can turn an otherwise harmless dog walk into a much grander endeavor.  Fortunately for me my dog is strong enough to carry me and smart enough to know how to get home.  So no matter what happens after my 17th cocktail I know I will arrive safe and sound. If you are in the neighbor hood check them out.  It is the best watering hole I have found in the Outer Sunset.

My favorite time to visit the Riptide is when the fireplace is lit and the bar isn't jammed to the gills with people. I know that they have live music, but I try to be out by the time that starts up - a bar that size doesn't lend itself to a lot of amplified sound. The bartenders are friendly and the patrons tend to be regulars and neighborhood folks. It's a basic neighborhood tavern, and I mean that in the best way.

Jerry convinced me to write a review of the Rip Tide.  I think of it as the rowdy cousin of the Beach Chalet.  Live music (not every night - call in advance), some dancing (by the bold only).  Generally a lively crowd - a nice mix of neighborhood sorts and wiseacres, no hipsters.  Generous pours, very friendly bartenders.  It has character and style, and is very welcoming, unlike some of the other Sunset/Parkside haunts where the established denizens make newcomers feel like lepers.

A dive bar if ever I've seen one with a very nice and cozy fireplace.  I hope the mounted moose head isn't real, but the mounted alligator or crocodile head is just too amusing to fret over!  Shots are $7... and they were huge ("Christmas special" said the barkeep).  There's a jukebox, a set of backgammon, Candyland, Connect Four, and a piano that I hope gets played every so often.

Best bet: Go on a "live music" night. Great country and bluegrass bands, fun party crowd (crazy locals, tourists, hippies, young and old). Some folks squeeze up by the band and dance.  www.riptidesf.comCheap drinks, very friendly staff.  It is a small, rustic dive bar that gets pretty packed and cozy by 10pm on a music night. If you plan on hanging for most of the night, get there early and grab one of the few tables against the wall. Pizza place next door has HUGE calzones. Stop there first then hit the Riptide.    I'm in a local band and this is my favorite place to play.

Enough ambiance, funky mix of folks from all over the place, cute chicks and young guys to ogle and be ogled - and a killer long island iced  tea.  Also, indian food/? pizza place next door.   And I thought Outer Sunset don't got no class.!

this is my favorite bar in the city.  why do you go to a bar?  to hang with your friends, meet cool people and drink (maybe even get drunk).  this is what happens at the Ripper.  Ive been there probably 4 dozen times and every time, all that stuff happens for me.  wierd! but prepare to be around some wasted people.  and i mean wasted.  people come here to drink. no messin around.

Great place with the best bartenders. Public transpo accessible. Decent parking and just a block from the beach. Very dog friendly. Surf movies shown every once in a while. Great special drinks. My fave...the Finger Bang! Now this is based on my taste but Bluegrass night and country western nights are just terrible. Unfortunately this usually happens on the weekends so I usually just go on the weekdays. Met some very cool people there and a decent pizza joint next door and the Bashful Bull across the street.
Rules. When is the next free oyster extravaganza?

Riptide alongside Brother's Pizza is in the running for the greatest places I visited in San Francisco. This bar, clearly a hangout for local yokels and young dive bar trawlers alike made me feel right at home from the second I stepped in.The tattooed lady running the bar greeted us as we walked in and although it was crowded it made me feel like a welcome friend even though I'd never beent here before. We eventually sidled up to the bar and got our drink orders in and when I handed her my credit card she quickly replied with "You're from LA, huh?" Apparently they don't take credit cards and the LA kids who come up for a visit always slap down the plastic when it comes to gettin plastered. Luckily I had cash on me because I was vacationing and we were shocked when our cocktail and beer added up to a grand total of 12 bucks. That's unheard of in LA!We continued our drinking by ordering up a couple carbombs which were the best value of the trip at $10 for both. Sweet. The locals chatted with us and gave us great suggestions for what to do while we were in town and really made our first night in San Francisco pretty great.

Just recently moved to the neighborhood and on a Saturday night thought I'd trot down there for a drink with my boyfriend and best friend.  We got there around 11 and inside is much nicer than the outside.  Decor seemed pretty cool inside...For my first time there it was NOT a great experience because as I was standing by the bar next to two guys (seemed like they were on date) one of the guys puked and barely contained the barf spewing through his hands! It was pretty nasty!  I moved away from that spot pronto !!!!  My boyfriend brought me my drink and we moved to the other side of the bar and sat at one of tables.  I may have to go back since my first time was not that great!

Holy crap, an open mic night that was GOOD!Now, I dont have anything against the concept of open mic.  God knows you'd never get me in front of a room full of strangers performing.  So I admire the courage it takes to get up there.  But...usually I just end up tuning out open mic nights in favor of drinking...anything.  Except I was lucky enough to stumble into the Riptide one night when we decided we would go carousing around the lovely dive bars of Parkside and the outer Sunset (on a Monday!  oh yeaahhh!).  And you know what?  There were some awesome people performing.  And there were doggies in the bar!  That was a plus.  Every night is themed differently so I'm going to have to go back and check out bluegrass night.

One of the deciding factors for moving to the outer Sunset is the proximity of my new abode to this great bar. On any given night you will run into: your contractor, your grandpa, your old surf buddy/bandmate, that hot girl you're always trying to impress and yes, your dog. They'll all buy you drinks...except your dog (he's a stingy little guy) and the girl (she's not into you dude). There will likely be DJs or a band or movies playing and there will probably be some sort of cheap communal grub available.What I want to know is. Why is it 9 blocks there and 15 back home?

Lately i've been doing a lot of thinking about life- and where i'm going, specifically, what type of old dude i'm going to be. The scienterifically executed polled consensus from my friend's seems to be i'll be that dirty old grandpa i'd thought i'd be. So with that in mind, its time for me to start  "dating" dive bars, looking for that one for me to call home and bring that old crotchety saltiness we all know and love from "that old guy" in the corner. What does that have to do with the Riptide? Read on.This place has got everything you'd want from a dive bar, and freakin' more! Good beers, wood panelling, distressed everything- and even some dogs running around. Awesome! Monday was open mike night and i've got to say, it was by far the best i've ever been to in the city- with everything from bluegrass to boogie woogie piano (!). The crowd was pretty freakin' cool too- hipsters mixed in with other regulars and everyone was getting along (could be the strong drinks). yah- apparently there are hipsters in the outer sunset- who knew. Probably a result of some porkbarrel diversity program spending that requires hipsters to be bussed out from Zeitgeist and Casanovas to other, less skinny-jeans wearing neighborhoods (read: outer sunset)I think I may have found a dive bar/future home of Tim V winner..... time to start getting old, who's gonna help me with being crotchety? Line forms on the left.....

The Riptide is a pretty fun bar, but I am not "allowed" to go because it is my husband's "club", where he goes free of ball & chain to get his drink on. Just to keep things lively, I occasionally do go to the "club", drag him out by the hair, berating him at the top of my lungs for drinking up the family's meal money and falling in arrears with support payments for his other kids. That's always a crowd pleaser!*******************(all of the above is untrue except that the Riptide IS a pretty fun bar, and the MIster prefers to drink with his BFF w/out the company of his wife.)It is a relaxed enough place that if I did drag him out by the short & curlies it would hardly raise an eyebrow. 5 stars.

What would I do if I was lucky enough to be out at Ocean Beach during an actual sunset?  Watch it from the Cliff House?  Watch it from the Beach Chalet?  Nah.  I'd stay on the beach and watch it, then walk over to Riptide for a beer.  For a city surrounded by water, we have precious few bars where you can actually smell the sea.  Throw in the wooden ship wheel decor, the neat double-sided bar, the trashy drink specials posted on the wall, the Beach Chalet's very own Riptide Red on tap, and a live band with harmonica that gets the place surprisingly packed with a lively but laid-back crowd from who-knows-where, and we might just have a winner in my search for a local bar (never mind that this is technically farther from my house than most places in the Mission--it's (extremely) west side and that's what counts).

It may be way the heck out there, but it's worth it. My boyfriend and I have met many great people there, the bartenders are all great and the free bluegrass/ old country live music has been awesome. The huge Schlitz globe and taxidermy remind me of home, while the surfboard on the wall reminds me that I'm not in Wisconsin anymore.

I love this bar.  They have an amazing selection of music on the jukebox, good bartenders, a fireplace, live music and white trash snacks.  My favorite part is that my dog is welcome here (but don't tell).  As far as I'm concerned, this bar and the Shannon Arms are the only good bars in my hood.
Everything a neighborhood bar should be!  All that and a real fire place.  I love this place.  I wish I lived nearby so I could visit more often.

I live two blocks away, and it's a shame I don't end up there more often.  Get to know your bartenders -- and they will serve you well.  Always quick and attentive service, no matter how big the order is! They have bands play there, they throw themed BBQs, usually have a DJ and a fireplace going, and when all else fails, a jukebox with a good selection.  Always a hoot! Crowd is anywhere from Rockabilly and Punk kids to Rednecks (where do they come out of?) and plenty of Irish.  Definitely a local hangout with a very warm vibe if you get into it.Fridays are the best.  So is the Moosehead that periodically smokes Parliaments.

This bar is over by my buddy Justin's house...only reason I've been out here...cause it's way the hell out there in the Sunset...but the few times that he can talk me to going out there, this is where we usually go, since it's only a few blocks from his house....As for the bar...I guess it's pretty cool...the people in there seem nice enough, no tools, stupid girls, stuff like that, at least from my experience...Minus 1 star because there is no Newcastle on tap, or even bottled, which always saddens me...but still, a pretty kick back bar for when you're out in the cuts of the Sunset

The first time I came to The Riptide was a few days after it first opened and I liked the relaxed, kick back atmosphere there.  After revisiting a few weeks ago, it's still relaxed and kick back, but no longer the type of place that I would go on a Friday/Saturday night to have a few.  I'm not sure if it's the clientele or what, but something about it is just amiss.  I can't describe what it is - it's just a feeling.  Although it's my closest local bar, I think I'd rather make a trip out to Yancy's for a drink (or ten).

Its dark and gross and dirty. But Im OK with that. They have a bunch of great beers including the riptide red, which I really like. The only thing I dont like about the riptide, is that sometimes my roommate goes there to troll for wang , and she brings home some real social undesirables.

Ahhhh the old Sand Bar! I used to love this place. I spent a lot of time here between 1999-2002. They had great bartenders and a great local following, young, old and hella old. The Mermen used to play/practice there on Sunday nights. It will always have a deeply special place in my heart and liver!Then it closed down....I went back when it re-opened only to find that the charm and the locals were gone. In fact some of the locals were asked not to come back. Not cool.They must of been cutting onions in the back because my eyes began tearing up. I guess I just miss the true 'Edge of the Western World' vibe this place once had.

I cant believe i lived out here in "the sticks" all this time and didn't make it here til recently...since then i'm attempting to make up with two visits in two weeks. The BBQ on Memorial Sunday was probably spectacular, but i was fashionably late and missed it but for some limp meat on a rickety table hovering all lonely looking by the bar. I'm sure that band was great too. Anyhow, me n me mates had a few beers, pissed off a couple of locals trying to pick us up, and lived up to our usual trick of being the last to leave. rah.all in all a fun time, loadsa single-looking surfer type vaguely punkish guys.10 out of 10 for the 'hood, cos frankly, there's fuck all else to do out here!!

Great dive bar!  I live about 20 blocks away and it's a great place to have a drink.  They're one of the most affordable bars in the area.  They have live music, open mic, and surfer movie night.  If you're near the beach it's a great place to stop in and have a Riptide Red Ale.

They've got one surfboard hanging on the wall, so I guess the name kind of fits. But it really seemed like it should have the word Lodge somewhere in the name, with the dead animal on the wall and the fireplace, etc. They've got beer and liquor along with an interesting cast of characters lining the bar...

The only redeeming quality this place has is the fireplace, which usually drunk 40 year olds are squawking around. Trashy bars in the Sunset are like aids in Africa. Rampant and full of flies.Sticky awkward tree tables and untrusty bathroom doors. I've walked in on many a huddled over drunk girl, trying to cover up her giblets. The only comfort drunk food they have are old Doritos. Weak.
This place is really fun, cheap drinks, good music, nice people.  Go here, get drunk, have fun :)

*******************************UPDATE*************************I was just informed *get this* that the owner of The Ridetide actually IS from Oklahoma! What an amazing coincidence! I was also informed by a member of the band that play the night I was there, the song about Jesus is actually making fun of born again christians. Even better! I must have missed the sarcasm in the singer's voice. I think I must give this Riptide another visit.******************************************************************This bar is WAY the heck out there... but it's still in the San Francisco city limits, right? Cuz from the look and sound of this place, I think I'm back in Oklahoma:1) There is a live country band. 2) The country band dedicated a song to all the "born-again Christians" in the crowd.3) The chorus from that song goes: "Me and my best friend, Jesus."4) There is a dead mammal hanging on the wall.However, I must say that the beer selection is much better than most Oklahoma bars. The Riptide also had plenty of tequila. I mean, with that country music playing,... what am I supposed to do? WHAT WOULD MY BEST FRIEND JESUS DO?

a friend that lives out here asked my wife and i out here for some beers and live music. we thought what the hell and went. i wish we would go here a little more often. riptide reminds me of san diego beach bars. riptide's people remind me of the surfer and flannel wearing beach dudes and gals. no hipster attitude (when is that going to die?) i like the live music and from the jukebox. good times and crowd way out there.strange how it is way out there and only be 3 or so miles from home. here in san francisco if you have to go 3 or 4 miles it can take a half hour maybe 45 minutes to get there. in san diego we didn't think twice about taking the car to the bar and twice as far and get there in minutes. long ago that is we don't drink and drive anymore. this is why we mostly stick to our mission 'hood and do our drinking there. anyway i like the riptide and will visit again soon.

Before I got married and my now husband lived around the corner form this bar, it was our usual spot.  The DJ on Fridays is the best.  Any DJ that has "Waiting Room" by Fugazi on rotation has got to be cool.  The Bluegrass bands kick ass also.  I'll keep on coming here, but I'm sure going to miss the 2 min drunken walk home...

I went here on a random Tuesday night and the place was very empty, which was the kind of place i was looking for. Needed some Fresh air, a few brews, and a heart to heart conversation with a ex co-worker letting out each others grievances on how our old job sucked and how our new ones are better.Don't know how busy this place gets during the weekends but will try it out sometime... Oh by the way any bar that leaves a KEG of Anchor Steam lying around the sea breeze smelling bathroom deserves 4 stars. So 4 stars to you Riptide.

I miss living across the street from this bar. When I lived there it was the sandbar and it was "on the edge of the western world". Nothing could be better. It has definitely upgraded in the years since I've moved away from the beach. The fireplace is a nice touch and the smell of the ocean air as you step outside is the best. I need to get back down there stat!

I can now proudly say I have danced on top of a bar. When the (sweet Alicia) bartender whisked me up during the DJ's offering of  "Rio" - I felt as if I could fall backwards into the lively crowd of 80's fans and be body bounced about ever so gently. Somehow I stayed on the bar, "dancing on the sand" with Durran Durran. A girlfriend had previously turned me onto the "skinny bitch" - Vodka and Diet Coke. This was my drink of choice in which I found pleasure in ordering and hearing myself do so. So, I ordered a few rounds for friends who then became hooked on the strangely good concoction.I was at the Riptide back in November of '04 - the day it "snowed" in San Francisco.  As a Michigan native, I found it funny to hear the "hail" called snow, but made no effort to correct people who so clearly were beyond thrilled. Anyhow - a photo of this day hangs on the wall at this bar, reminding me how long I have been boozing it up at this fun little quirky outer sunset neighborhood spot. Monday's are great for open mic., Friday's there is usually a great 80's style DJ - michael. And, Saturday's really good live music. Check out the calendar online for more details as they also have happy hours and other events.

Stiff, reasonably priced drinks, coupled with wood paneling, a giant brick fireplace, and those indearing old-timers that remind you not to drink so much, the riptide is one of those great, dive-y (but not too much) neighborhood bars.  Expect Rock & Roll on the jukebox, mostly metal or punk, but occasionally the obligatory Johnny Cash, and eccletic music acts on the weekends. The regulars are friendly, as is the staff, and they've got a good selection of beers on tap for a small bar. Not the place to go if you want neon lights and thumping house music.Oh, and the bar is cash only, but they've got an atm in the corner.

man i remember the sandbar. when i had my fill of all things asian up taraval, id hit up sandbar. one drunken night, i was stammering around, went outside for a smoke and looked up. wtf, this isnt sandbar. i was all trippin. holy shit, am i THAT drunk i thought i was at sandbar the whole time, but this place is called riptide?(insert usual drunken screaming "HOOOOOOOOLY SHIIIIIIIIIIT IM FUUUUUUUUUUUUUCCKED UP. HAHAHAHHAHAHAH oohohoh AHHAHAHHAHAHHA  i thought this was sandbar the whole time, but its not. HAHAHHAHAHAHA" )cool dive bar at the end of taraval. makes the pizza next door taste good.

If you're not a regular here you know it right away. Despite that, the staff is very nice, and the atmosphere is cozy. The jukebox is so good I want to hug it. Open mic nights on Mondays, free food on Fridays, random bands throughout the week, all in the Sunset. What more could you want? Oh yea, clean bathrooms. They have those too.
Somebody took a dirty, scary little bar in the outer-sunset (the Sand Bar) and turned it into a cozy, fun place to hang out with the locals. Nice.

I miss the original sign that hung outside of a black spray painted shark and the words, "The Riptide" sloppily written! Even though it has been replaced with the oh-so fancy neon sign I'd still hang out and drink there! It's one of my favorite neighborhood bars where you can watch surf videos or Napoleon Dynamite while some random musicians perform for open mic night! Bartenders are always friendly and don't skimp on the booze in your cocktail! Also, you can listen to a great selection of music on the jukebox - you mean I can hear Danzig and Al Green back to back? The bonus - longshoremen hang out there too! Well grizzly looking guys who seemed to have been hanging at the docks all day!

I mourned the passing of The Sand Bar when it changed hands and closed for renovation.  When it was reborn as The Riptide, I approached the front door fearing the worst...that of a tragic remodel involving sheet-rock walls, cheesy neon lamps, and a tolling of the bell for yet another neighborhood watering hole. Thankfully, The Riptide's new owners didn't ruin the place.  To the contrary, they've performed the delicate balancing act of cleaning up a decomposing neighborhood bar while leaving it's rustic charm largely intact.  The result is a place that's changed for the better.  Years of filth have been scoured away, and decrepit timbers have been replaced. But still, the hearty soul of a meeting place with history  remains. A central bar sits in the middle of the room, with most of the seating on the West side.  TV's for sports are small, but decently placed.  Limited wood on the walls along with a brick fireplace help create a humble ambiance with a rough-cut charm.  It's an overall feel that no cut-and-gut remodel with new materials and contemporary styling could ever duplicate.   The mid-day/after-work crowd is an odd mix: An easy-going group of young surfers  and a smaller segment of old-guard codgers.  Later at night the clientele gets younger as the beach crowd trickles in and the music gets turned up. All in all, I like it.  It's a friendly mix of young and old where the two actually interact.  And while the night crowd gets a little young and noisy for my tastes, I could really see liking it when I was in my twenties. It's out of the way, it's near the beach, and there's a pizza place two doors down.  I've came, I've seen, I'll be back....

After work this comfortable and unassuming bar offers cheap pints, friendly dogs, a happenin' music selection in the juke box, smiling bartenders, and Connect Four. Really, think about it...when was the last time you sat down with a lovely pint of "your favorite beer" (in my case, Anchor Steam), a group of good friends, and Connect Four?! If you can't remember, go to the Riptide. Originally I listed this as a 4 star...adding the fifth because every time I have been there, the bathroom has been very clean!

So disappointed b/c I had such high hopes.  Our first time there, we loved it-- the fireplace, the feeling of being in a Northwoods bar.  But, the second trip there ruined it for me.  We had the whole family from Madison in town to visit.  On our drive along the oceanside, we stopped off at Riptide for a beer during the afternoon, and they kicked us out because we had a kid with us.  We weren't buying her beer-- we bought her a coke and planned to play cards in the middle of the afternoon. Instead, the bartender demanded she show ID, even though she was with both her parents, and then made her wait outside while the beers that he had already tapped were drunk.  Some chronic at the bar chimed in with, "you should've charged them double for smuggling in a child."  Turns out the Northwoods look of the place is just that.

When I sauntered into this extreme Outer Sunset bar I was welcomed by a warm presence of locals and a roaring fire.  I then realized I think I have found my favorite San Francisco bar, and one close to my house.  Located right off the MUNI L and at the cusp of the Pacific Ocean, the Riptide offers cheap drinks, Guinness on tap and a plethora of music options ranging from alt-country to bluegrass.  They have happy hour specials throughout the week, but the special thing about this place is the remodeling job that brought the true character out including knotty pine walls and the lodgey northwoods feel.  For a truly honest drink poured by friendly bartenders and surrounded by locals, stop into the Riptide.

This little dive bar--just a few blocks from the beach--is almost (but not quite) enough to tempt me to move to the Outer Sunset. Expect friendly, welcoming regulars (some with their dogs), great beer and one kick-ass fireplace.

This is one of the coolest neighborhood dive bars I've ever set foot in, and it *would* be the coolest had I never set foot in Madison, Wisconsin.  Rustic seafarer's pub meets knarly surfer dood saloon.  Cool fireplace, cheap drinks, good pizza next door, board games, friendly staff and customers, good eye candy, ample parking in front, live music and free food. Not a pretentious post-greek Marina a-hole for miles.  Good all around.

Earlier this week I was sitting by a fire, roasting marshmallows on a stick while enjoying a $3.50 pint of Guinness and a $2 pint of Hefeweizen.  No, we didn't stop at a liquor store on the way to a bonfire on Ocean Beach- we were hanging out indoors at this bar.  They actually have sticks for roasting things by the fireplace, and on Wednesdays they're providing sausages and shish kabobs!  And it's right next to an L stop.  Need I say more?

This is the hippest bar in the sunset. Inside the tiny space, large deer horns lord over the dimly lit bar. I arrived on open mic night to find a fifty year old man playing cover tunes on his electric keyboard. This was followed by two guys playing punk covers of Neil Diamond songs. Wow. They have their own brand of Riptide Red Ale. The owners and bartenders are super friendly. The Riptide rocks. Live Music 2 nights a week.
